facts.text: Writ Petition No. 17 of 1965 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 17 of 1965. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights. D. Karkhanis, E. C. Agarwala and P. C. Agarwala, for the petitioner.

facts.text: Petitioner is a trader at Meerut.

anchor.surface_text: Shah, J. The petitioner. who is a trader at Meerut was ordered by the Income-tax Officer, D-Ward, Meerut, to pay Rs. 1,800/- as annuity deposit under Ch. XXII-A of the Income-tax Act, 1961.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer, D-Ward, Meerut ordered petitioner to pay Rs. 1,800 as annuity deposit under Chapter XXII-A of Income-tax Act, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Shah, J. The petitioner. who is a trader at Meerut was ordered by the Income-tax Officer, D-Ward, Meerut, to pay Rs. 1,800/- as annuity deposit under Ch. XXII-A of the Income-tax Act, 1961.

facts.text: Petitioner challenged validity of demand and Chapter XXII-A as unconstitutional and violative of Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner has filed this petition challenging the validity of the demand on the plea that Ch. XXII-A of the Income-tax Act is unconstitutional and is otherwise violative of the fundamental right guaranteed by Art. 14 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Indian Income-tax Act, 1961 enacted by Parliament to consolidate and amend law relating to income-tax and super-tax.

anchor.surface_text: The Indian Income-tax Act 43 of 1961 was enacted by the Parliament to companysolidate and amend the law relating to income-tax and super-tax.

facts.text: Income-tax Act, 1961 came into force on April 1, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The Act came into force on April 1, 1962.

facts.text: Parliament enacted Finance Act, 1964 to give effect to financial proposals for 1964-65.

anchor.surface_text: The Parliament enacted Finance Act 5 of 1964 to give effect to the financial proposals of the Central Government for the financial year 1964-65, and by S. 3   1   of that Act it was provided

facts.text: Section 44 of Finance Act, 1964 introduced Chapter XXII-A (ss. 280-A to 280-X) into Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: By s. 44 of the Finance Act, Ch. XXII-A relating to annuity deposits companytaining ss.280-A to 280-X was introduced into the Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Annuity deposits required for assessment year commencing April 1, 1964 (1964-65) onwards for certain taxpayers.

anchor.surface_text: Save as otherwise provided in Chapter XXII-A of the Income-tax Act, annuity deposit for the assessment year companymencing on the 1st day of April, 1964 shall be made by every person to whom the provisions of that Chapter apply

facts.text: Annuity deposit rates prescribed in Second Schedule to Finance Act: 5% to 12.5% on adjusted total income exceeding Rs. 15,000.

anchor.surface_text: By the Second Schedule to the Finance Act, rates of annuity deposits are prescribed. The deposit has to be made by the specified categories of taxpayers, having a total income exceeding Rs. 15,000 at the prescribed percentages rising from 5 to 12 1/2

facts.text: Taxpayers liable: resident individuals (Indian citizens), HUF, unregistered firms, AOP, body of individuals (not company or co-op), artificial juridical persons (not statutory corporations).

anchor.surface_text: A taxpayer who is a resident and falls within any of the following categories is liable to make the annuity deposit an individual, who is a citizen of India, a Hindu undivided family, an unregistered firm, an association of persons or a body of individuals, whether incorporated or number  other than a companypany or a companyperative society , and an artificial juridical person

facts.text: Exempt from annuity deposits: non-residents, companies, co-operative societies, corporations established by Central/State/Provincial Acts.

anchor.surface_text: All number-residents and all companypanies and companyporations and company operative societies established by Central State or Provincial, Acts are accordingly exempted from the operation of the annuity deposits scheme.

facts.text: Taxpayer may opt not to make annuity deposit by notice to ITO before June 30 of assessment year; option irrevocable.

anchor.surface_text: But a taxpayer who is required by s. 280-A, to make an annuity deposit may exercise his option number to make it, by a numberice in writing to the Income-tax Officer before the 30th of June of the assessment year. The option once exercised is irrevocable

facts.text: If opt out, pay income-tax plus additional income-tax equal to half the amount saved by not depositing; exemption if over 70 years on last day of previous year.

anchor.surface_text: and operates in respect of the assessment year and all subsequent years. The taxpayer who exercises the option has to pay beside the income-tax payable on his total income, additional income-tax which is equal to half of the amount which he saves by number making the deposit.

facts.text: Petitioner contends Parliament lacked competence for Ch. XXII-A as it relates to borrowing by Central Government.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner submits that the scheme of annuity deposit incorporated in Ch. XXII-A is invalid because  a  the Parliament had numbercompetence to incorporate in the Indian Income-tax Act, a provision which was substantially one relating to borrowings by the Central Government from a class of taxpayers

facts.text: Petitioner contends Ch. XXII-A is colourable exercise of legislative power, harsh, unconscionable, expropriatory.

anchor.surface_text: b  the provisions companytained in Ch. XXII-A are enacted in companyourable exercise of legislative power, and that in any event they are so harsh and unconscionable that they may be regarded as expropriatory

facts.text: Petitioner contends s. 280 and Sch. II discriminatory, infringe Art. 14.

anchor.surface_text: c  the provisions of s. 280 and Sch. II are discriminatory and infringe the fundamental freedom under Art. 14 of equality before the law.

facts.text: Court holds no substance in petitioner's contentions; Parliament competent under Entry 82 and 97 List I.

anchor.surface_text: In our view there is numbersubstance in any of the companytentions. The Parliament has by Art. 246 read with Entry 82 in List I of the Seventh Schedule power to levy taxes on income other than agricultural income.

facts.text: Annuity deposit scheme for higher income groups, repayable in 10 annual instalments with interest.

anchor.surface_text: Broadly stated, the scheme of Ch. XXII-A is that certain classes of taxpayers in the companyparatively higher income groups are required to make out of their total income deposits at the specified rates on the adjusted total income, with the Central Government. The amount so deposited is made returnable with interest in ten annual instalments.

facts.text: Petition dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The petition fails and is dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Hidayatullah J. delivered separate opinion agreeing to dismiss petition.

anchor.surface_text: Hidayatullah, J. I agree that this petition should be dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Income-tax Act utilizes machinery for assessment and collection of annuity deposits.

anchor.surface_text: The power of assessment, and companylection of annuity deposit is entrusted to Income-tax Officers, and the machinery of the Income-tax Act is utilised for that purpose.

facts.text: Annuity deposit deductible in computing total income for tax.

anchor.surface_text: The amount of annuity deposit payable by a taxpayer in any year is admissible as a deduction in companyputing his total income charged to tax for that year.

facts.text: Penalty up to 50% for failure to pay annuity deposit by due date.

anchor.surface_text: A taxpayer who fails to pay the annuity deposit by the due date is exposed to a penalty which may amount to as much as 50 of the deposit required to be made by him.

facts.text: Objective of scheme: mobilize savings, curb inflation.

anchor.surface_text: What is sought to be achieved by the Act is the twin objective of mobilisation of private savings for public purposes and imposing curbs on the inflationary trends in the economy of our companyntry.

holdings.text: There is no substance in any of the contentions regarding Parliament's lack of competence; Parliament has power under Art. 246 read with Entry 82 List I to levy taxes on income other than agricultural income, covering Ch. XXII-A.

anchor.surface_text: In our view there is nosubstance in any of the contentions. The Parliament has by Art. 246 read with Entry 82 in List I of the Seventh Schedule power to levy taxes on income other than agricultural income.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ch. XXII-A integrated with income-tax levy; uses same machinery; enacted under power for taxes on income.

holdings.text: Power to legislate for annuity deposits also within competence under Entry 97 List I residuary powers.

anchor.surface_text: Granting that the scheme of Ch. XXII-A is for borrowing money by the Central Government from the taxpayers in the higher income group at the rates prescribed, which is repayable in instalments, power to legislate in that behalf is still within the competence of the Parliament by virtue of Entry 97 of List I of the Seventh Schedule.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Even if viewed as borrowing, covered by residuary entry.

holdings.text: No prohibition against incorporating provisions under multiple List I entries, including residuary, in single statute like Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: But if the Parliament has the power to legislate for collecting annuity deposits from taxpayers, there is nothing in the Constitution which disentitles the Parliament as a matter of legislative arrangement to incorporate the provisions relating to borrowing from taxpayers in the Income-tax Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: Matter of convenience; machinery shared with income-tax; avoids duplication.

holdings.text: Ch. XXII-A is not a colourable exercise of legislative power.

anchor.surface_text: The argument that Ch. XXII-A is - a colourable exercise of legislative power has nosubstance. As pointed out by this Court in K. C. Gajapati Narayan Deo and others v. The State of Orissa

holdings.reasoning_summary: Doctrine applies only to transgression of powers; here Parliament acts within competence; cites precedent.

holdings.text: Provisions of Ch. XXII-A not so harsh, unconscionable or expropriatory as to be invalid; taxing statutes not challengeable merely for being harsh or excessive.

anchor.surface_text: a taxing statute is subject to the conditions laid down in Art. 13 of the Constitution. A taxing statute may accordingly be open to challenge on the ground that it is expropriatory or that the statute prescribes noprocedure

holdings.reasoning_summary: Subject to Art. 13; invalid only if expropriatory or no procedure; cites Moopil Nair.

holdings.text: Provisions of s. 280 and Sch. II not discriminatory and do not infringe Art. 14.

anchor.surface_text: Article 14 of the Constitution guarantees equality before the law, and equal protection of the laws. But thereby the power of the Legislature to make a reasonable classification of persons, objects or transactions for attaining certain objectives

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reasonable classification (income slabs >15k, residents, age >70 exempt) has rational nexus to mobilizing savings and curbing inflation.

holdings.text: Pith and substance of Ch. XXII-A is taxes on income under Entry 82 List I.

anchor.surface_text: It is always necessary to examine the pith and substance of any law impugned on the ground of want of legislative competence with a view to ascertaining the precise entry in which it can come.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Annuity deposit alternative to tax; integrated machinery; belongs to income-tax topic (Hidayatullah J.).

holdings.text: Annuity deposits not borrowing under Art. 292/366(4); legislative tax relief scheme.

anchor.surface_text: It is argued that this is a case of borrowing which is defined in Art. 366 4 to include the raising of money by the grant of annuities, and loan is also required to be construed accordingly.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Executive power on Consolidated Fund security; here alternative to income-tax.

holdings.text: Not covered by List II Entry 30 (money-lending).

anchor.surface_text: Entry No. 30 money- lending, and money lenders has to be mentioned and rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Does not apply to annuity deposits (Hidayatullah J.).

holdings.text: Entry 97 residuary not to be first resort; use only after exhausting specific entries.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Examine pith and substance first; residuary last resort.
